articles.title: Paris Agreement set path to slow warming, but the world hasn't stayed on it
articles.summary: The world has changed dramatically in the decade since leaders celebrated a climate agreement in Paris a decade ago. The planet's annual temperature jumped about 0.46 degrees Celsius (0.83 degrees Fahrenheit) since 2015, one of the biggest 10-year temperature hikes on record. Earth has been hit repeatedly with more costly, dangerous and extreme weather.

articles.title: Landmark Paris Agreement set a path to slow warming. The world hasn't stayed on it
articles.author: Upworthy
articles.summary: Paris Agreement set a path to slow warming, but the world hasn't stayed on it. It's due to expire on 09 November 2025.      Â   .   - Paris Agreement is not enough to slow global warming.

articles.title: UN says refugees stuck in vicious circle of conflict and climate
articles.summary: UNHCR is urging the COP30 summit to provide financing for the most vulnerable. By mid-2025, 117 million people had been displaced by war, violence and persecution. Three in four of them are living in countries with high-to-extreme exposure to climate-related hazards.

articles.title: UN says refugees stuck in vicious circle of conflict and climate
articles.author: The Straits Times
articles.summary: Climate shocks are increasing humanitarian needs and amplifying the risks of repeated displacement, according to the UNFCCC. Read more here: straitstimes.com.       .   ...   for confidential support call the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline on 1-800-273-8255.

articles.title: The alarming climate science data world leaders can't ignore at COP30
articles.summary: This year, global temperatures are climbing faster than before, with new records logged for 2023 and 2024, and at points in 2025. The world is on track to cross the 1.5 C warming threshold around 2030, after which scientists warn we will likely trigger catastrophic, irreversible impacts. Extreme weather and other impacts are taking an increasing toll on populations and environments across the globe.

articles.title: Heat singes workers; A'bad, Surat among worst hit
articles.author: Parth Shastri
articles.summary: Ahmedabad and Surat are among the top 5 cities in India affected by heat stress. Migrant labourers in India face increased heat stress driven by climate warming and ENSO variability. Mumbai has the highest migration inflow of job seekers in India with more than 1.7 million people.

articles.title: Caricom climate change centre to represent region at COP30 in Brazil
articles.author: Vanassa Mckenzie
articles.summary: Caribbean Community Climate Change Centre (CCCCC) will lead regional representation at the 30th Conference of the Parties (COP30) to be held in Belém, Brazil, later this year. The CCCCC will host the Caricom Pavilion, a dedicated space for Caribbean nations to engage global stakeholders and advocate for climate justice and sustainable development.

articles.title: Interactive map shows deforestation drives up tropical temperatures by up to 5°C
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: Online map reveals link between deforestation and rises in tropical temperatures. Deforestation is leading to temperature increases of up to 5°C in some tropical regions, according to a new interactive map created by researchers at the University of Leeds. It has important implications for human health, water security, agriculture, and climate resilience.

articles.title: FLOP 30: Is the Climate Hoax Finally Over?
articles.author: Freedomsphoenix Readerfour
articles.summary: Bill Gates has changed his mind about climate change. Michael Mann has written a screed excoriating Bill for his climate scare-mongering. Bill's spending on the climate crusade is actually increasing. The timing of the blog announcing the change of mind is important as it was released on the eve of COP30.

articles.title: Tackling Climate Change Without the U.S.
articles.author: Katrin Bennhold
articles.summary: This week leaders from around the world are meeting in Belém, Brazil, for their annual climate talks. For the first time since the meetings began 30 years ago, the U.S. is not sending any top officials. Donald Trump has called climate change a hoax and is in the process of withdrawing from the Paris Agreement for the second time. The hope now lies with China and emerging economies to pick up the slack.

articles.title: Taliban Protests Afghanistan's Exclusion from Climate Summit
articles.author: Africa
articles.summary: Afghanistan's National Environmental Protection Agency (NEPA) expressed deep concern over the fact that Afghanistan has not received an official invitation to the UN Climate Change Conference in Belém, Brazil. Afghanistan is one of the world's most climate vulnerable countries. The Taliban government has sought to position itself as a responsible environmental steward despite widespread international isolation over human rights concerns. Syrian President Ahmed al Sharaa attended the summit.

articles.title: Arctic Blast & First Snow: East Coast Weather Update
articles.summary: 70% of the continental United States could experience temperatures 10 to 20 degrees below normal in the coming weeks. The current cold snap is a signal that established weather patterns are being disrupted, with potentially far-reaching consequences for agriculture, energy grids, and even the insurance industry. The immediate concern is the impact on infrastructure and public safety. Many climate models suggest that a changing climate doesn't mean uniformly warmer temperatures, but more extreme weather events.

articles.title: Anyone with robins or sparrows in garden this winter issued 'twice a day' rule
articles.author: Alex Evans
articles.summary: Gardeners are being urged to feed common British birds like robins and sparrows during the cold winter months. The RSPB recommends putting out bird food and water on a regular basis through autumn and winter. House sparrow numbers in England declined by 71% between 1977 and 2008.

articles.title: The world was 1.4C hotter through August than in the pre-industrial age
articles.author: Moneyweb
articles.summary: Global heat streak threatens Paris climate target, according to the UNFCCC. It's been very hot in recent days, which is not good for the environment. It is also bad for people's health. It makes it more vulnerable to climate change. It also makes it worse.

articles.title: Rising Polar Vortex Threat for US, Asia and Europe Signals Higher Winter Energy Bills
articles.author: News Feed Editor
articles.summary: Rising Polar Vortex Threat for US, Asia and Europe Signals Higher Winter Energy Bills, according to the Bloomberg.com article. The article is an adaptation of the article from the Bloomberg website, which can be read as a source of information by clicking on the link below.

articles.title: Earth's Next Supercontinent Is Forming Right Now
articles.summary: Scientists say that a new supercontinent is already in the works, with landmasses converging over tens of millions of years. In this video, Bright Side traces how Africa, Australia, and Antarctica might merge and explores what that means for climate, oceans, and you.

articles.title: Flood emergency in Pirri: "Work has been stalled for too long, bold action is needed now."
articles.summary: The storm that hit Cagliari last night caused flooding in Pirri. The municipal president Maria Laura Manca is calling for urgent action to prevent future problems. The most critical phase of the rain occurred between 12:23 and 12:48 am, bringing the water level to 50/60 cm near Via Balilla.

articles.title: Homes are collapsing in Outer Banks. It could spell trouble for other coastal areas, too
articles.author: Samantha Delouya
articles.summary: Stacy Morgan and Brandon Dodick bought their beach house in Buxton, North Carolina, in May. Five months later, their house was destroyed by the ocean. Since 2020, 27 beachfront homes on Hatteras Island have collapsed into the ocean due to rising sea levels and relentless storms. The safety net designed to protect homeowners from flooding is frozen due to the government shutdown. Lat Williams is relocating his home to save it.

articles.title: The face of neglect: Woman with nasal cancer in Gibara without access to treatment
articles.author: Ciber Cuba Editorial Team
articles.summary: Emilia Velázquez Caballero lives with cancer in her nose and mouth in the municipality of Gibara, Holguín. She lives with her husband, who is bedridden and needs medication, vitamins, and food. She earns very little and can't afford to buy groceries.

articles.title: Farmers call for urgent action on spreading Wilding Pines
articles.author: NZ Herald
articles.summary: High country farmer, Simon Cameron, says invasive trees are threatening farmland and native ecosystems. Simon Cameron is a farmer in the High Country of the United States. He is concerned about the impact of the trees on farmland and ecosystems.    .   i

articles.title: HEADLINE: 'Climate Change Riskscapes and Strategies for Women and Girls of Indonesia'
articles.author: Stephen Heins
articles.summary: Climate change disproportionately impacts women and girls in Indonesia. This chapter highlights the transformative power of gender-responsive programs. Empowering women is essential for building climate resilience at the community, national, and global levels. The successful programs highlighted in this chapter serve as powerful examples of what is possible when gender equity is prioritized.

articles.title: Landmark Paris Agreement set a path to slow warming. The world hasn't stayed on it.
articles.author: SETH BORENSTEIN
articles.summary: The world has changed dramatically since leaders celebrated a historic climate agreement in Paris a decade ago. Earth's warming climate has gotten nastier faster than society has been able to wean itself from burning the coal, oil and natural gas that emits carbon pollution that triggers global warming.

articles.title: Landmark Paris Agreement set a path to slow warming. Nations haven't stayed on it.
articles.author: Class
articles.summary: The world has changed dramatically since leaders celebrated a historic climate agreement in Paris a decade ago, but not in the ways they expected or wanted. More than a degree Celsius (2 degrees Fahrenheit) has been shaved off future warming projections since 2015. The lack of enough progress will be a big focus for the next two weeks as diplomats gather in Belem, Brazil, for annual UN climate negotiations.

articles.title: Decade After Paris Agreement, Experts Say World Has 'Failed' To Halt Warming
articles.author: Associated Press
articles.summary: The world has changed dramatically in the decade since leaders celebrated a historic climate agreement in Paris a decade ago. The planet's annual temperature jumped about 0.46 degrees Celsius (0.83 degrees Fahrenheit) since 2015, one of the biggest 10-year temperature hikes on record. Earth has been hit repeatedly with more costly, dangerous and extreme weather.

articles.title: HEADLINE: 'The False Temperature Claims That Underpin The COP30 Alarmist Agenda', Authored by Chris Morrison
articles.author: Stephen Heins
articles.summary: The foundation scam is that the world is warming dramatically, leading to tipping points and worsening extreme weather. Professor Mark Maslin is a Professor of Earth Systems Science at UCL and one of the authors of a recent tipping point report timed for COP30. In 2018 he was one of a number of eco-activists who signed a letter to the Guardian saying they would no longer debate climate change sceptics.

articles.title: Landmark Paris Agreement set a path to slow warming. The world hasn't stayed on it
articles.author: ABC
articles.summary: The world has seen faster climate change than expected since the Paris Agreement a decade ago. The planet's annual temperature jumped about 0.46 degrees Celsius since 2015. This year will be either the second or third hottest on record. Developed countries have reduced their carbon dioxide emissions by about 7% since 2015, but other countries have seen their emissions soar.

articles.title: CARICOM climate change centre to represent regional at COP30 in Brazil
articles.author: Nationnews Desk
articles.summary: Caribbean Community Climate Change Centre (CCCCC) will lead regional representation at the 30th Conference of the Parties (COP30) to the UNFCCC to be held Belém, Brazil. The CCCCC will host the CARICOM Pavilion, a dedicated space for Caribbean nations to engage global stakeholders and advocate for climate justice and sustainable development.

articles.title: Landmark Paris Agreement set a path to slow warming. The world hasn't stayed on it – abcnews.go.com
articles.author: News Feed Editor
articles.summary: Paris Agreement set a path to slow warming, but the world hasn't stayed on it.   iReport.com: Paris Agreement is not working as it was supposed to, because the world isn't staying on the path to reduce global warming.  Report.

articles.title: 'Tino' leaves P40M agri, P9M infra damage to WVisayas
articles.author: Rjay Zuriaga Castor
articles.summary: Typhoon Tino caused nearly P40 million in production losses across more than 1,400 hectares of cropland in Region 6 (Western Visayas). Iloilo province sustained the highest agricultural losses at P18.27 million, followed by Guimaras at P9.78 million and Antique at P7.04 million. The storm also damaged 12,773 houses across Aklan, Antique, Capiz, Iloila and Guimar as well as 317 homes totally destroyed. Super Typhoon Uwan has disrupted sea travel across nine seaports, stranding 758 passengers, 357 rolling cargoes and five vessels.

articles.title: Flood-risk alert for Bangkok, Pathum Thani, Nonthaburi
articles.author: Online Reporters
articles.summary: The Royal Irrigation Department raised the discharge rate from 2,750 to 2,800 cubic metres per second on Sunday after heavy inflows from northern rivers caused by remnants of Storm Kalmaegi. The increased water discharge has pushed water levels higher along the Chao Phraya River and its tributaries, raising the risk of overflow and flooding in nearby areas.

articles.title: Gates climate memo is the wrong message at the wrong time
articles.author: Class
articles.summary: The UN's 30th Climate Change Conference kicks off on Monday, Nov. 10, in Brazil. Bill Gates is a co-founder of Microsoft and one of the wealthiest and most philanthropic people on the planet. In his Oct. 27 memo, he argues that the doomsday view of climate change is inaccurate. The world has reached record levels of heat that scientists say is driven largely by the burning of fossil fuels. In Washington, there are drought, wildfire, and ocean acidification.

articles.title: Lake life: The migration
articles.author: David Fabio
articles.summary: Sandhill cranes are migrating from northern Canada to the Gulf States. Grantsburg, Wisconsin and Sherburne Nature Area in Minnesota serve as stopovers for the migration. During this time, up to 10,000 birds can be found in each area, resting and feeding. The harvested fields south of town are teeming with activity.

articles.title: First snowfall in effect for Ontario, residents warned to watch for wet snow, ice
articles.summary: David Phillips, a climatologist at Environment and Climate Change Canada advises residents to drive cautiously. Watch the video to find out more about David Phillips' advice to drive safely. iReport.com: Do you know David Phillips? If so, email him at davids@eccc.ca.

articles.title: Now is the time to act on climate change, not to do nothing
articles.summary: Despite what the government says climate change is not going away, John Drummond writes that it is accelerating. The government has halved its targets for reducing methane emissions and removed any obligation on businesses worth less than $1 billion to report on their plans to reduce their carbon emissions. Winston Peters and David Seymour are sceptical about climate change. The National party has traditionally been the party of the farmers.

articles.title: Former NHS nurse, 83, desperately searching for food and shelter after Hurricane Melissa
articles.author: James C. Reynolds
articles.summary: Mira Morrison, 83, has run out of food and shelter after Hurricane Melissa hit St. Elizabeth parish in Jamaica. Her granddaughter Bianca Montiqu has started a GoFundMe page to send a shipping container full of essentials to Jamaica. She raised more than £700 in three days and expects £3,000 to cover the cost of filling, storing and sending the shipping container. Bianca also wants to send lumbar, wood, steel beams and bricks to help build better homes.

articles.title: Typhoon Fung-wong: Philippines Evacuations & Deaths
articles.summary: Super Typhoon Fung-wong devastated the Philippines, displacing over a million people and claiming lives. The increasing frequency and intensity of typhoons in the Philippines is directly linked to climate change. The Philippines has made strides in disaster preparedness, including pre-emptive evacuations of over 1.2 million people ahead of the typhoon. The future of disaster response must prioritize proactive measures, such as investing in more sophisticated weather forecasting technology.

articles.title: Progress vs peril: A decade after Paris deal, world still off-track on 1.5°C goal
articles.summary: A decade after the Paris climate accord, the world faces faster warming, worsening disasters and uneven progress. Since 2015, more than a degree Celsius has been shaved off future warming projections, but the world remains far from its central goal, limiting global temperature rise to 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels. The UN Environment Programme warns that without steep cuts in emissions, current policies put the world on a path closer to 2.8°C of warming.

articles.title: Landmark Paris Agreement set a path to slow warming. The world hasn't stayed on it
articles.author: The News-Gazette
articles.summary: The world has seen faster climate change than expected since the Paris Agreement a decade ago. Scientists say Earth's warming has outpaced efforts to reduce fossil fuel pollution that came out of the 2015 accord. This issue will be a hot topic in the coming years.

articles.title: Landmark Paris Agreement set a path to slow global warming. The world hasn't stayed on it
articles.author: News Staff
articles.summary: The world has changed dramatically in the decade since leaders celebrated a historic climate agreement in Paris a decade ago. The planet's annual temperature jumped about 0.46 degrees Celsius (0.83 degrees Fahrenheit) since 2015, one of the biggest 10-year temperature hikes on record. The decade since 2015 has seen the most Category 5 Atlantic hurricanes and the most billion-dollar weather disasters in the United States.

articles.title: Landmark Paris Agreement set a path to slow warming. The world hasn't stayed on it
articles.author: Seth Borenstein
articles.summary: The world has changed dramatically since leaders celebrated a historic climate agreement in Paris a decade ago. Earth's warming climate has gotten nastier faster than society has been able to wean itself from burning the coal, oil and natural gas that emits carbon pollution that triggers global warming.

articles.title: Landmark Paris Agreement set a path to slow warming. The world hasn't stayed on it
articles.author: SETH BORENSTEIN
articles.summary: The world has changed dramatically in the decade since leaders celebrated a historic climate agreement in Paris a decade ago. There's been progress, but the progress has been slower than the acceleration of climate's harms. The lack of enough progress will be a focus for the next two weeks as diplomats gather in Belem, Brazil, for annual UN climate negotiations.

articles.title: Landmark Paris Agreement set a path to slow warming. The world hasn't stayed on it
articles.author: Seth Borenstein
articles.summary: The world has changed dramatically in the decade since leaders celebrated a historic climate agreement in Paris a decade ago. Earth's warming climate has gotten nastier faster than society has been able to wean itself from burning the coal, oil and natural gas that emits carbon pollution. The planet's annual temperature jumped about 0.46 degrees Celsius (0.83 degrees Fahrenheit) since 2015. This year will be either the second or third hottest on record. America has been hit by 193 disasters that cost at least $1 billion in the past 10 years for a total bill of $5 trillion.

articles.title: Landmark Paris Agreement set a path to slow warming. The world hasn't stayed on it
articles.author: SETH BORENSTEIN
articles.summary: The world has changed dramatically in the decade since leaders celebrated a historic climate agreement in Paris a decade ago. The planet's annual temperature jumped about 0.46 degrees Celsius (0.83 degrees Fahrenheit) since 2015, one of the biggest 10-year temperature hikes on record. The decade since 2015 has seen the most Category 5 Atlantic hurricanes and the most billion-dollar weather disasters in the United States.

articles.title: Scotland's Draft Climate Change Plan: 2026–2040
articles.author: biologyphenom
articles.summary: Scotland was the first country in the world to declare a climate emergency and established the world's first Just Transition Commission in 2019. Since then over 1,000 schools per year have been engaged as part of climate action schools where prizes are on offer for those working together to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions. Gillian Martin, Cabinet Secretary for Climate Action and Energy, spoke at the Scottish Parliament this week.

articles.title: It's been a dangerous decade since the Paris Climate Agreement, but there's still reason for hope
articles.author: News Feed Editor
articles.summary: It's been a decade since the Paris Climate Agreement, but there's still reason for hope, says CNN's John Sutter, who is optimistic about the future of the climate change.    "There's still hope for the future" says Sutter.

articles.title: Global South Leaders Demand Climate Reparations at COP30
articles.summary: COP30 in Belém will take place from November 10-21, 2025. African leaders will use it to push for a shift to non-debt climate finance instruments to address a $2.5 trillion shortfall. World Meteorological Organization data shows 2015-2025 will be among the warmest years, with 2025's temperature 1.42°C above pre-industrial levels.

articles.title: Survey finds 40% of Australian women without kids hesitant to have children because of climate change
articles.author: Donna Lu
articles.summary: Half of Australians are concerned about climate change and two in five believe the climate will be 'much hotter' in 2050. More than a third of Coalition voters do not believe in climate change. Labor, Greens and independent voters are three times more likely to express high levels of concern than conservative voters. Women are more concerned about the changing climate than men.

articles.title: What Questions Do You Have About Climate Change?
articles.author: Katrin Bennhold
articles.summary: Somini Sengupta writes about climate change and how people are coping with life on a hotter Earth. If you have questions for Somini about climate politics, the state of the climate or what it's like to cover global warming when the world is preoccupied with many other crises, fill in the form below. Somini will pick a few questions to answer in The World.

articles.title: The Injustice of Climate Crisis Grows Ever Clearer
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: The increasing ferocity and frequency of tropical storms imposes an unbearable burden on countries including Jamaica, says the editorial.    Jamaica's government is responsible for the increase in the number and ferocity of these storms.  It's a problem for Jamaica's people.

articles.title: Landmark Paris Agreement set a path to slow warming. The world hasn't stayed on it
articles.summary: The world has seen faster climate change than expected since the Paris Agreement a decade ago. This issue will be a focus of this week's UN climate talks in Brazil. (Produced by Julián Trejo Bax)    for CNN iReport.

articles.title: UN warns world plunges into Climate Crisis as 1.5°C goal slips away
articles.summary: The global struggle against climate change has reached a devastating moment. WMO data confirms Africa is warming faster than the global average. The Global North emits 75 percent more greenhouse gases than the Global South. The rising heat exacerbates local crises in Africa. The adaptation costs for sub-Saharan Africa are estimated at $70 billion annually by 2030.

articles.title: Trump tariffs and strict US border rules threaten flight of Canada's ‘snowbirds'
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: Annual migration from frigid Canadian winter to Florida sunshine could become thinner as travellers look elsewhere. Hundreds of thousands of Canadian 'snowbirds' escape freezing temperatures in their homeland and go to Florida every year.    "Snowbirds" are people who live in Canada and travel abroad.

articles.title: Late arrival of flamingos to Navi Mumbai wetlands, Thane creek sign of environmental stress: Experts
articles.author: PTI
articles.summary: The delayed arrival of flamingos in Navi Mumbai's wetlands and Thane Creek is a warning sign of increasing environmental stress, experts say. The prolonged monsoon and post-monsoon rains this year are believed to be the cause. Wetlands are vital "blue carbon" sinks, storing vast amounts of carbon and reducing flood risk.

articles.title: Antarctica Is Melting Faster Than Expected, Scientists Sound Alarm
articles.author: NDTV
articles.summary: Antarctica is approaching irreversible climate thresholds, scientists warn. Rapid melting of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet, record-low sea ice, and collapsing ocean systems could raise global sea levels.       .   "Antarctic Ice Sheet is melting rapidly.

articles.title: COP30: Asean experts want a realistic agenda to steer region from climate crisis
articles.summary: World leaders are meeting at COP30 in Belém, Brazil since Thursday to discuss climate change. South-East Asian climate advocates are calling for a clear regional agenda to influence climate policies. Weather-related disasters are destroying lives, rivers, and farmland across the region. Timor-Leste is one of the most vulnerable, as 70% of the population relies on subsistence farming.

articles.title: Scientists record fastest Antarctic glacier retreat in modern history
articles.author: 3 minute read
articles.summary: Hektoria Glacier on the eastern edge of the Antarctic Peninsula has undergone the fastest recorded retreat in modern history, losing nearly half its length in just two months. Hektoria Glacier shed eight kilometres of ice at a pace not seen since the end of the last ice age. The glacier's rapid retreat was driven by the shape of the land beneath it.

articles.title: Expert shuts down widespread misconception about global phenomenon: 'The fingerprints point to us'
articles.author: Misty Layne
articles.summary: Expert shuts down widespread misconception about global phenomenon: "The fingerprints point to us". Some TikTok users still believe the sun is responsible for the heating of Earth. The actual cause of increased warming is human activity that results in heat-trapping gases being released into the atmosphere.

articles.title: As COP30 kicks off, should young people feel optimistic about fighting climate change?
articles.author: Ariella Cook-Shonkoff
articles.summary: The annual United Nations Conference of the Parties on Climate Change kicks off on Monday in Brazil. Donald Trump's administration has dismantled clean energy investments, weakened regulatory bodies and removed federal protections for national parks and green spaces. A delegation of 30 children from Belem, Brazil has been trained as Climate Justice Ambassadors by Plant-for-the-Planet and will represent children globally at COP30.

articles.title: 2025 among hottest years ever as global temperatures soar, seas rise and ice melts
articles.summary: The past 11 years (2015-2025) have been the warmest in recorded history, according to the World Meteorological Organization. The average global temperature between January and August 2025 was 1.42°C above pre-industrial levels. Concentrations of greenhouse gases reached record highs in 2024 and continued to rise in 2025. Ocean heat content also hit new records.

articles.title: It's time to address how we actually survive climate change
articles.summary: Chris Bowen will join the Australian delegation at the COP30 climate change talks in Brazil this week. Climate change is reshaping Australia now. The government's recent National Climate Risk Assessment shows that Australia's homes, health, food systems and ecosystems are under increasing strain due to climate change. Chris Bowen is calling for a national commitment to invest 0.25 per cent of GDP annually in climate resilience.

articles.title: Earth heats faster as climate crisis deepens globally
articles.author: Maleeha Zahid
articles.summary: The planet is warming 50% faster than it did in previous decades. The average global temperature is increasing by 0.27°C per decade, compared to 0.2°C in the 1990s and 2000s. Sea levels are rising more quickly, reaching 4.5 millimeters per year over the past decade. Earth's natural systems are showing alarming signs of collapse. The Amazon rainforest could transform into a savannah-like ecosystem if deforestation and global warming persist.

articles.title: 8 colour-changing birds and how they do it
articles.author: TOI Trending Desk
articles.summary: Some birds change the colour of their feathers with the seasons. Some do it to hide from predators, some to attract mates, and others to blend in better with their surroundings. The Ruff has one of the most dramatic seasonal changes. The Scarlet Tanager is bright red with black wings in summer and yellowish-green before migration. The Bohemian Waxwing changes its look in a gentler way in winter.

articles.title: Climate crisis accelerates as scientists warn of tipping points and deadly heat
articles.author: Zuha Shahzad
articles.summary: The planet is warming at 0.27°C per decade, 50% faster than in the 1990s and 2000s. Scientists predict the world will surpass the 1.5°C warming threshold by 2030, bringing irreversible climate impacts. Heatwaves are emerging as the most lethal climate impact. Half the global population is now struggling with heat stress.

articles.title: Climate change, population growth pose serious threats to Pakistan's economy: Saif Ur Rehman
articles.summary: Saif Ur Rehman is the coordinator to Federal Tax Ombudsman. He warned that rapid population growth and climate change pose serious threats to Pakistan's economy. He urged the government to adopt coordinated measures, including population management strategies through education, awareness campaigns, and family planning programs.

articles.title: Triad residents get a taste of cold weather this week
articles.author: John Hinton
articles.summary: Arctic cold front will arrive in North Carolina on Sunday night. Triad residents will experience cold temperatures Sunday night through Tuesday night, forecasters say.    .   i   in the Triad area.  In the rest of the state, it will be warmer.

articles.title: President Mary Robinson: The realities of smallholder farmers must take center stage at COP30
articles.author: Mary Robinson
articles.summary: Smallholder farmers grow a third of the world's food and nearly 70% of Africa's. They receive less than 1% of all climate finance. Over 150 disasters attributable to climate change occurred in 2024, and farmers are already being battered by droughts, floods, new pests and diseases. The aid sector's depictions of smallholders reinforce misconceptions about who they are.

articles.title: Afghanistan Excluded From UN Climate Change Conference in Brazil
articles.author: ATN
articles.summary: Afghanistan has been excluded from the upcoming international climate change conference in Brazil. Afghanistan is one of the most vulnerable nations to climate impacts. The conference is scheduled to begin tomorrow (Monday). NEPA emphasized that, with a coordination mechanism and a comprehensive roadmap prepared, the Afghan government can take part in the conference.

articles.title: As Cop30 begins in Brazil amid intensifying climate change, what's the latest in science?
articles.summary: Temperatures are rising at a faster rate than in the 1990s and 2000s. Sea levels are rising faster now too, at about 4.5mm per year over the last decade. The world is on track to cross the 1.5 degrees Celsius warming threshold around 2030.

articles.title: Philippines: Millions Brace for Super Typhoon Impact
articles.summary: 900,000 Filipinos evacuated ahead of Super Typhoon Fung-wong (Uwan), following closely on the heels of Typhoon Kalmaegi, which claimed over 200 lives. The geography of the Philippines makes it uniquely susceptible to typhoons. The escalating intensity of these storms, fueled by warming ocean temperatures, is pushing the nation beyond its coping capacity. The immediate consequences of these super typhoons are devastating: widespread flooding, landslides, infrastructure damage, and loss of life. The ripple effects extend far beyond the initial impact, including food insecurity and economic hardship. The Philippines is facing a potential crisis of climate refugees.

articles.title: WMO report warns: 2025 among hottest years ever as global temperatures soar, seas rise and ice melts
articles.summary: The past 11 years (2015-2025) have been the warmest in recorded history, with 2023, 2024, and 2025 ranking as the three hottest years ever observed. The average global temperature between January and August 2025 was 1.42°C above pre-industrial levels. The report paints a troubling picture of record-breaking heat, melting ice, rising sea levels, and more frequent extreme weather events. The number of countries with Multi-Hazard Early Warning Systems (MHEWS) has more than doubled from 56 in 2015 to 119 in 2024.

articles.title: Letter: Climate case doesn't account for nature
articles.summary: Professor Chip Fletcher wrote an op-ed about the cause of climate change. Clint Churchill is president of Practical Policy Institute of Hawaii. Bill Gates recently pivoted on his climate change position, lamenting about 'too much focus on near term emissions goals'. Hawaii's policymakers should make a similar pivot.

articles.title: Is your kitchen at risk from climate change? It's closer to home than you think
articles.author: David Simon
articles.summary: There are increasing numbers of homes being damaged or destroyed by flooding and other disasters due to climate change. The frequency of such flooding is increasing and its nature is changing. Global leaders are gathering in Bélem, Brazil for COP30, this year's edition of the annual summit of the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change.

articles.title: Voices: Is your kitchen at risk from climate change? It's closer to home than you think
articles.author: David Simon
articles.summary: There are increasing numbers of homes being damaged or destroyed by flooding and other disasters due to climate change. The frequency of such flooding is increasing and its nature is changing. Global leaders are gathering in Bélem, Brazil for COP30, this year's edition of the annual summit of the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change.

articles.title: [OPINION] Super typhoons and the value of geological hazard assessment
articles.author: Glenda Gloria
articles.summary: Today, the entire country awaits the landfall, around Quezon and Aurora provinces, of Super Typhoon Uwan (Fung-wong) later in the evening. In the Philippines, the Engineering Geological and Geohazards Assessment (EGGA) system was institutionalized in March 2000 as an institutional tool to safeguard development projects from hazards caused by geological phenomena.

articles.title: The gutting of county Cornwall
articles.author: Howard Campbell Nbsp
articles.summary: Melissa, the second most devastating hurricane in world history destroyed Cornwall county 48 hours after the storm. 95 per cent of Cornwall county is affected and more than half of the poor are homeless. Damage to infrastructure has to be borne by the Government and will cost billions of US dollars. Foreign aid has begun to be disbursed with the use of foreign helicopters.

articles.title: DEC lowers 'drought warning' for Warren, 20 other counties
articles.author: Nys Dec
articles.summary: Warren County has been moved from drought warning to drought watch status. Several weeks of consistent rainfall and improving levels of streamflow and ground water have improved the situation in Warren County, New York State Department of Environmental Conservation announced.       .

articles.title: Include workers in climate decisions: trade unions
articles.author: Star Business Report
articles.summary: Bangladesh is one of the world's most climate-vulnerable countries. The National Alliance for Just Transition Bangladesh (NAJTB) called for a worker-centred climate action plan that guarantees decent work, social protection, and inclusion of workers in policymaking. NAJTB also wants a gender-sensitive budget to support women workers in climate-resilient sectors.

articles.title: Researchers sound alarm after catastrophic discovery in ocean: 'The race is on'
articles.author: Christine Dulion
articles.summary: Global Tipping Points report warns that Earth has already passed one of the first environmental tipping points: the large-scale decline of warm-water coral reefs. It says the planet is dangerously close to several other tipping points involving ice sheets, ocean currents, and the Amazon rainforest. Coral reefs support a quarter of all marine species and sustain the livelihoods of hundreds of millions of people.

articles.title: Climate tipping points are close: scientists urge radical action before it's too late
articles.author: Laura Pereira
articles.summary: The world has reached the first of many Earth system tipping points, which will cause catastrophic harm unless humanity takes urgent action. Global temperatures in both the atmosphere and oceans have recently spiked. Oceans are absorbing 90% of extra heat from the earth that isn't absorbed by plants. The International Court of Justice ruled recently that world leaders must take immediate action on climate change.

articles.title: Climate change education needed
articles.author: NWA Online
articles.summary: We must accept that climate change is not a theory any more. The facts are so overwhelming that the facts are overwhelming that we need to accept it.    - John Sutter, author of the book "Theory of Climate Change is No More"

articles.title: Philippines Braces for New Typhoon Fung-wong After Kalmaegi
articles.summary: There is an increasing frequency and intensity of tropical cyclones impacting the Philippines due to climate change. Over 200 lives were lost in the wake of Super Typhoon Kalmaegi and there is a looming threat of Super typhoon Fung-wong (Uwan) in November 2023. The future of climate resilience in the Philippines lies in leveraging data and technology to improve predictive modeling and early warning systems.

articles.title: Waterfowl hunters adjusting to tweaked bag limits
articles.summary: Changes in recommendations from the Pacific Flyway Council prompted an increase in the northern pintail duck bag limit from one to three in Washington and Idaho. The Washington goose bag limit was reduced from four to three per day in some areas and three to two in others. Idaho's bag limits remains at five per day for Canada geese.

articles.title: Scotland's draft climate plan targets net zero by 2045
articles.author: Glen Barclay
articles.summary: Scottish Government has published a draft plan to eliminate greenhouse gas emissions by 2045. It includes targets to phase out new petrol and diesel cars by 2030, expand woodland and peatland restoration, and decarbonise heating systems in homes and businesses. The plan has immediately faced criticism from farmers, environmental groups and opposition MSPs.

articles.title: Hurricane Melissa:
articles.author: BBC News
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa hit the Caribbean last month. Iona Walker is worried for her family. She is a volunteer at the Afro-Caribbean National Artistic (ACNA) centre in St Ann's. She has not been able to keep in touch with them.

articles.title: South Kerry residents have differing views after seawater breaches dunes of Derrynane beach
articles.author: Jack Joy
articles.summary: Seawater breached the dunes at Derrynane this week. Some locals want to see measures taken to prevent the land being lost to water, while others believe little should be done to prevent natural erosion. The dunes that were breached are on the 'inside' of the spit, which has the sea to its west.

articles.title: Climate Disasters In Pakistan: The Cost Of Neglect And The Need For Urgent Action
articles.author: Ghazala Anbreen
articles.summary: The recent floods in Pakistan were caused by climate change. Pakistan contributes only a small fraction of global CO₂ emissions, but it is contributing to global warming to some extent locally. The developed world wants to help Pakistan to mitigate the adverse effects of climate change, but they need reassurance that the money they provide is being used effectively to tackle the problem.

articles.title: Climate change fuelling land fragmentation in West Nile
articles.summary: The Ministry of Agriculture, Animal Industry and Fisheries recognises land fragmentation as a key challenge undermining agricultural productivity in Uganda. The problem is largely driven by rapid population growth and traditional inheritance practices. There is no specific policy framework directly targeting land fragmentation, leaving farmers to grapple with low efficiency, reduced yields, and declining household incomes. The situation has been worsened by the growing refugee population that relies on limited food supplies.

articles.title: Climate threat may return Broads to Roman landscape
articles.author: Owen Sennitt
articles.summary: John Packham is the outgoing chief executive of the Broads Authority. He has overseen the management of the broads in Norfolk and Suffolk for 25 years. Climate change is one of the biggest challenges for his successor. Land will have to be given up to be used as floodplains.

articles.title: Climate change threatening Norfolk and Suffolk Broads
articles.author: Owen Sennitt
articles.summary: John Packham is the outgoing chief executive of the Broads Authority. He has overseen the management of the broads in Norfolk and Suffolk for 25 years. Climate change is one of the biggest challenges for his successor. Land will have to be given up to be used as floodplains to protect homes.

articles.title: In Frames: Andhra's coastal village Uppada on the brink
articles.author: K.R. Deepak
articles.summary: The village of Uppada in Kakinada district of Andhra Pradesh has been losing an average of 1.23 metres of coastline per year, with 1,360 acres eroded in the past five years alone. Cyclone Montha battered the coast two weeks ago, damaging at least a dozen houses within two days. A new Rs. 323-crore seawall proposed by the National Centre for Coastal Research offers short-term protection, but the long-term future remains uncertain.

articles.title: Maharashtra: Climate disruption leaves Palghar's coastal families reeling under massive losses
articles.author: Megha Parmar
articles.summary: Unseasonal rains and cyclones destroyed dried fish worth '100 crore' from Palghar's 112-km coastline. Nearly one lakh fisherfolk are on the brink. The community was granted an agricultural status, but the state government denies them the disaster relief packages.

articles.title: The Climate Issue newsletter: China, the climate superpower
articles.summary: This year will be the second- or third-hottest year on record, extending the run of exceptional temperatures that kicked off in 2023. China's lead in global manufacturing is bigger than ever, thanks to the growth of renewable energy industries. The Economist's China team edited a special report on this growth this week.

articles.title: Climate Anxiety among young people in Guyana
articles.author: Staff Reporter
articles.summary: Guyana and the Caribbean have experienced many environmental changes in recent decades due to climate change. The concept of 'climate anxiety' is being recognised as the feelings of anxiety and fear that we experience about the growing concerns surrounding the state of our planet and environment. The more we understand climate justice and environmental science, the more we recognise how our actions affect the environment around us.

articles.title: Landmark Paris Agreement Set a Path to Slow Warming. The World Hasn't Stayed on It
articles.author: WKMG
articles.summary: The fight against climate change within the UN has gone through its worst moment since the signing of the Paris Agreement a decade ago. The world is better prepared than ever to displace the principals responsible for the problem, writes Simon Tisdall, because of global warming.

articles.title: Column: Teaching climate change in Arkansas schools
articles.summary: 20 states require some form of Climate Change or Environmental Awareness to be taught in their schools. California has passed a bill that would mandate it in all higher grade public schools. The subject has become a political issue, because it is being denied and called a hoax by some politicians.

articles.title: Coalition Senator Andrew Bragg issues shock ultimatum as pressure on Opposition Leader Sussan Ley mounts ...
articles.author: The Daily Mail
articles.summary: A senior Liberal has warned his party would push Australia towards joining 'baddies' in rejecting international climate goals as it prepares to back fossil fuel-fired power. The political infighting within the Coalition has intensified over the issue.

articles.title: ‘Simply not true': John Anderson rips apart Andrew Bragg's defence of net zero, says international community deserting climate policy
articles.author: Charlie Tchetchenian
articles.summary: Andrew Bragg said on Sunday he would resign from the frontbench if the Liberal Party abandoned the Paris Agreement on climate change. John Anderson said the international community was 'walking away' from its climate commitments. The Liberal Party has maintained a policy of achieving net zero by 2050 since 2021. The Nationals voted last Sunday to dump the party's commitment to achieve it by 2050.

articles.title: UN calls for major climate funding boost to shield frontline communities
articles.author: Data Analyst
articles.summary: Ten years after Paris Agreement, the world is still heading for more than 2 degrees of warming. The longer the world stays above this limit, the more extreme events will intensify. UN Secretary-General António Guterres stressed that a just energy transition must protect people on the frontlines, especially those whose livelihoods depend on fossil fuels. UN Climate Change Executive Secretary Simon Stiell urged countries to submit stronger NDCs backed by real financial resources.

articles.title: Ho Chi Minh City promotes sustainable aquaculture development
articles.author: Vietnam
articles.summary: Coastal localities in Ho Chi Minh City are turning aquaculture into a strategic path for sustainable growth as natural marine resources continue to decline.   Â   in the city's coastal areas are turning it into a source of economic growth.

articles.title: As COP30 gathers, what's the latest in climate science?
articles.author: Alison Withers
articles.summary: Global temperatures are climbing faster than before. Sea levels are rising faster now too. The world is on track to cross the 1.5 C warming threshold around 2030. Scientists warn we will likely trigger catastrophic, irreversible impacts. U.S. President Donald Trump is trying to slash funding for climate and weather research.

articles.title: COP30: The latest in climate science, from faster warming to coral collapse
articles.author: Alison Withers
articles.summary: This year, global temperatures are climbing faster than before. Sea levels are rising faster now too. The world has warmed by 1.3-1.4 C since the pre-industrial era. The U.S. administration under Donald Trump is trying to slash funding for climate science.

articles.title: Experts issue warning after observing concerning shift in the Arctic: 'A lot of what we have today will be lost'
articles.author: Mariah Botkin
articles.summary: Experts issue warning after observing concerning shift in the Arctic: 'A lot of what we have today will be lost' as the region's food web is unraveling. Melting ice accelerates global sea-level rise, while the loss of reflective snow cover traps more heat in the atmosphere, worsening warming everywhere.

articles.title: The False Temperature Claims That Underpin The COP30 Alarmist Agenda
articles.author: Tyler Durden
articles.summary: The next two weeks of COP30 will promote the hard-Left Net Zero fantasy about runaway temperatures and human-caused climate change. Chris Morrison is sceptical about the theory that the world is warming dramatically and that it's caused by humans. He points to the fact that over 600 million years CO2 has generally been declining in the atmosphere.

articles.title: EXPLAINER -As COP30 gathers, what's the latest in climate science?
articles.author: Reuters
articles.summary: This year, global temperatures are climbing faster than before. Sea levels are rising faster now too. The world is on track to cross the 1.5 C warming threshold around 2030, after which scientists warn we will likely trigger catastrophic, irreversible impacts. The U.S. administration under climate-denying President Donald Trump is hoping to slash funding for science.

articles.title: In pics: migration of snow geese in Canada
articles.author: Xinhua
articles.summary: Tens of thousands of snow geese migrate each year from Russia's Siberia to southern British Columbia of Canada and the U.S. state of Washington to feed and rest before flying south to California for wintering. Snow geese take off over Iona Beach in Richmond, British Columbia, Canada, Nov. 8, 2025.

articles.title: Is it too late? Researchers warn West Antarctic Ice Sheet at ‘extreme risk' of collapse
articles.author: Akanksha Mishra
articles.summary: Antarctica is on the brink of irreversible changes to its ice, oceans and ecosystems. The West Antarctic Ice Sheet is at 'extreme risk' of collapse, which could raise global sea levels by over three metres. The loss of sea ice and increasing sea levels are also threatening wildlife populations. Chinese fruit called NRK-C reduced fasting blood glucose by up to 40%, improved insulin sensitivity by nearly 50%, and restored metabolic balance in mice with diabetes.

articles.title: Scientists issue warning after discovering major change in massive natural feature: 'This is really a lot'
articles.author: Robert Crow
articles.summary: Glacier-monitoring organization GLAMOS reports that Switzerland's glaciers lost 3% of their ice mass this year. The Rhone Glacier, Europe's largest during the Ice Age, lost nearly 1.5 meters in thickness during this hydrological year. In the past decade, Switzerland has lost 25% of its glacier volume and between 2016 and 2022, about 100 glaciers disappeared. Global warming is caused by heat-trapping pollution pumped into the atmosphere.

articles.title: Liberals risk joining 'baddies' with fossil-fuel push
articles.author: Tess Ikonomou
articles.summary: "Australia needs to be in Paris, in my opinion, and then we need to find a way to do net-zero better than Labor. That is better for jobs, better for industry and better for decarbonisation."    "It's better for the environment. It's better on jobs."

articles.title: Liberals risk joining 'baddies' with fossil-fuel push
articles.author: Tess Ikonomou
articles.summary: A senior Liberal has warned his party would push Australia towards joining "baddies" in rejecting international climate goals. The party is preparing to back fossil fuel-fired power as it prepares to back the Paris Climate Agreement's goals.

articles.title: New study raises alarms about ecosystems that may be on verge of irreversible collapse
articles.author: Drew Tuma
articles.summary: Temperatures are predicted to rise past the 1.5 degrees Celsius rise compared to pre-industrial levels within the next five years. The first casualty could be the planet's coral reefs. An estimated 80% of them are now being affected by the worst mass bleaching event on record. The COP30 conference is being held in Brazil next week.

articles.title: Filipinos must lead the way to make climate polluters pay
articles.author: POINT
articles.summary: Philippines is bracing itself for another super typhoon. This year's climate crisis highlights the importance of Filipino voices in climate negotiations. House Bill 4420 or the Climate Accountability (CLIMA) Bill was filed in the 20th Congress. If passed, the law will ensure that frontline communities have a fighting chance by establishing accountability mechanisms to make climate polluters pay.

articles.title: Cosmic dust reveals dynamic shifts in central Arctic sea-ice coverage over the last 30,000 years
articles.author: Space Daily
articles.summary: Arctic sea ice has declined by more than 42% since 1979, when regular satellite monitoring began. Seattle, WA (SPX) Nov 07, 2025 Arctic Sea Ice Declined by 42% Since 1979, When Regular Satellite Monitoring began. As the ice is declining, so is the population.

articles.title: PALM Scheme safe, Australia confirms
articles.author: FBC News
articles.summary: The Australian High Commission has raised concerns over false claims suggesting the Pacific Australia Labour Mobility Scheme is being touted by the media. The claims are not true, according to the High Commission's official statement. The statement is based on information provided by the Media Research Centre.

articles.title: As COP30 gathers, what's the latest in climate science?
articles.author: Dawn
articles.summary: The pace of climate change is speeding up. Extreme weather and other impacts are taking an increasing toll on populations and environments across the globe. Global temperatures are climbing faster than ever before.      Â   in this year's developments in climate science.

articles.title: Climate change threatening Norfolk and Suffolk Broads
articles.author: BBC News
articles.summary: John Packham is the outgoing chief executive of the Broads Authority. He has overseen the management of the broads in Norfolk and Suffolk for 25 years. He warns climate change is "biting hard" and could dramatically change the waterways. He outlines the biggest challenges for his successor.

articles.title: Managing climate change
articles.author: Ali Tauqeer Sheikh
articles.summary: The solution to climate disasters must shift from humanitarian aid appeals to prearranged and guaranteed financial liquidity. Small island nations like Barbados and Jamaica have learned that climate resilience is not just about securing finance but about social responsibility. Pakistan's response to the 2022 Pakistan floods and Hurricane Ivan's impact on Jamaica in 2004 were very different. Jamaica invested in building 850 emergency shelters and upgrading infrastructures.

articles.title: Climate report: Earth on dangerous path but rapid action can avert the worst outcomes
articles.author: Steve Lundeberg Guest Article
articles.summary: 2024 was the hottest year on record and likely the hottest in at least 125,000 years, according to an annual report issued by an international coalition led by Oregon State University scientists. 'Without effective strategies, we will rapidly encounter escalating risks that threaten to overwhelm systems of peace, governance, and public and ecosystem health,' said William Ripple.

articles.title: As Cop30 begins, what's the latest in climate science?
articles.author: South China Morning Post
articles.summary: Extreme weather and climate change are taking an increasing toll on populations and environments across the globe. Here are some of the worst-case scenarios for people and places affected by climate change and extreme weather events.       .   "The future is uncertain"

articles.title: Americans are moving out of flood-prone neighborhoods
articles.author: Bennington Banner
articles.summary: The American neighborhoods with the highest risk of floods are again losing residents due to the floods.      Â   y   in the U.S. are losing residents because of the floods, because they are at risk of flooding.

articles.title: Feel like winter yet? GTA residents wake up to season's first dump of snow
articles.author: Toronto Sun
articles.summary: The snow should melt fairly quickly. There is still uncertainty about the track of the weather system. The forecast snowfall amounts may change, so the forecast may be subject to change as well.   The advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

articles.title: Letter: Climate case doesn't account for nature
articles.author: Star Advertiser
articles.summary: Professor Chip Fletcher wrote a recent op-ed about the cause of climate change and humans contribute to global warming. He insults Professor Fletcher, but all agree that humans are responsible for climate change, so let's all agree on that.    .

articles.title: Survey finds 40% of Australian women without kids hesitant to have children because of climate change
articles.author: The Observer
articles.summary: 40% of Australian women without kids are reluctant to have children because of climate change. Half of Australians are concerned about climate change and two in five believe the climate is getting hotter. Women expect the climate to get hotter and are more anxious and insecure due to the changing climate.

articles.title: Pacific leaders demand action ahead of COP30
articles.author: FBC News
articles.summary: Fiji's survival and the future of other Pacific island countries depend on keeping global warming below 1.5 degrees, according to the UNFCCC report.    .   "The future of Fiji and other Pacific Island countries depends on keeping the temperature below 1,5 degrees"

articles.title: What Questions Do You Have About Climate Change?
articles.author: New York Times
articles.summary: 'Ask a Correspondent' will take your questions to Somini Sengupta, our international climate reporter. She will answer your questions about climate change.    Sengupta is a reporter at CNN's international news service, "Aquiline".

articles.title: Caricom climate change centre to represent region at COP30 in Brazil
articles.author: Jamaica Observer
articles.summary: Caribbean Community Climate Change Centre (CCCCC) will lead regional representation at the 30th Conference of the Parties (COP30) to be held in Belmopan, Brazil later this year. CCCCC will host the Caricom Pavilion, a dedicated space for Caribbean nations to engage global.
